metadata.title: Bill To Regulate Online Gaming Gets Cabinet Nod, Next Stop Lok Sabha

left: The Union Cabinet approved a Bill to prohibit real money games online, affecting platforms like Dream11 and PokerBaazi, on August 19, 2025.
This Bill represents a major change in the Union government’s approach to the real money gaming sector.
The Bill allows e-sports tournaments to collect entry fees without violating the prohibition on real money games.
Anyone offering such money games could face a jail term of up to three years and a fine, according to the Bill.
center: India's Union Cabinet approved a bill on Tuesday to regulate online gaming by targeting platforms linked to betting and gambling.
This legislation emerged due to rising public concerns over harm from real-money gaming, including reported suicides and addictive behaviors among youth.
The bill, expected to be introduced in the Lok Sabha tomorrow, includes strict penalties, fines, app bans, and prohibits celebrity endorsements of betting-linked games.
In the financial year 2023-24, India's online gaming sector earned $3.8 billion in revenue, with real-money gaming contributing $2.4 billion and fueling a 23% growth compared to the previous year.
If enacted, the bill could significantly disrupt the sector, potentially leading to business closures, job losses, and reshaping how companies operate in India’s gaming market.
right: The Central Government of India has approved a bill to regulate online gaming platforms associated with betting and gambling, introducing strict penalties and fines for violations.
The bill prohibits celebrities and public figures from endorsing gaming apps tied to betting, aiming to protect youth from exploitation.
This regulation comes amidst rising concerns about the addictive nature and financial risks posed by unregulated platforms, particularly to younger audiences.
If passed, this legislation will significantly change India's online gaming landscape, creating a safer environment for young users.
